Column No : 1241

MOLESTATION AND RAPE CASES

     1.  Mdm Cynthia Phua asked the Minister for Home Affairs with regard to recent reports in the Straits Times on molestation and rape cases, (a) how many of these cases were victims who are known to the culprits;  (b) what are the measures taken to reduce these incidents;  and (c) are there any public education programmes in the schools, as many victims were very young teenage girls.

 

 

 

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs):  Mr Speaker, Sir, Madam Cynthia Phua asked for the number of rape and molestation cases where the perpetrators were known to their victims. For the period 2000 to June 2004, the perpetrator was known to or acquainted with the victim in 9 out of 10 reported cases of rape.  For the same period, 3 out of 10 reported cases of outrage of modesty were committed by persons known to the victims.

 

     To deter would-be perpetrators, the Police conducts patrols at entertainment nightspots and their vicinity to maintain a visible presence. The Police works closely with residents, grassroots organisations and other agencies to enhance the safety in the neighbourhoods.  These initiatives, under the Community Safety and Security Programme or CSSP framework, include fixing additional lighting to brighten public places at night, setting up neighbourhood watch groups, organising joint patrols and house visits involving Police and residents and holding talks and exhibitions.

 

     The Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Police have been educating students that they too have a part to play in preventing molest and rape. Schools conduct public education programmes to educate our young on personal safety and prevention of sexual abuse. These are comprehensively covered in subjects such as Civics and Moral Education, Social Studies, and Health Education. Police complements MOE's efforts by conducting school assembly talks to educate students on what they can do to prevent themselves from falling victim to rape and molest.  So far, 99 such talks have been conducted this year.

 

      Let me assure the House that we view every case seriously. Whilst Police will continue to maintain its presence to deter potential perpetrators and take the necessary enforcement actions, members of the public can also help by taking an active role in ensuring their own personal safety as well as of those around them.

 

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister how come an American, Jack West, 58 years old, who is a sex offender, was able to enter Singapore and to teach in schools here and investigations were only instituted after the New Paper reported of his presence in Singapore.

 

     Secondly, should the sponsors of a work pass applicant be made accountable and asked to undertake the due diligence checks before recommending him to the Ministry for processing?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:  Sir, for foreigners who come to work in Singapore, we do not carry out checks with their home countries whether they have got criminal records.  As to whether the Ministry of Manpower could carry out such checks, I think a balance has to be struck.  In answer to a question from Ms Irene Ng on the need for checks to be done on employees, I said that we have to maintain a balance.  There are certain professions which, because of sensitivity, for example, if you work in a security area, checks need to be done, but not so in this case.

 

 

     Mdm Cynthia Phua:  Sir, since many of these victims are very young girls, should not our schools be more secure in the sense that either the Ministry of Law or the Ministry of Home Affairs as well as the Ministry of Education should check all these work permit applicants before they are employed in Singapore?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:  Sir, I think we should separate the issues.  In terms of the security of school premises, as Mdm Phua knows, this has been beefed up.  In terms of strangers going to schools, whether it is for mischief such as terrorism or even for more down-to-earth matters as disturbing the students, both in terms of possible sexual abuse or even gang activities, the schools have beefed up too.  Certainly, for workers working in school premises, the schools can carry out due diligence checks but it will be quite another thing to say that all those who work with the school should also be checked for their background.  This may mean rolling back what we are trying to do to help people who have a record but have turned over a new leaf to be able to work productively.

     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member):  Sir, can I ask the Minister whether he would consider it a preventive measure, especially when foreigners come in to set up student agencies, etc, to do a background check.

 

     The second question is for those who have been convicted for molest or rape, what kind of rehabilitation programmes are carried out and whether there are repeat offenders amongst them and, if so, what is the rate?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:  Sir, the conducting of checks on foreigners coming in to set up agencies involving children is something which is within MOM's purview.  I can ask MOM to consider that.

 

     As for the other question, the Prisons Department has got this 3R programme which generally reaches out to prisoners to help them refresh, restrain and exercise responsibility.  Whether it is sexual offence or other offences, as the Member knows, the Prisons Department takes this HUMANS approach  to try to help the prisoners after they have served an initial period of confinement and they have felt the punishment.  For sexual offenders, they are also taken under this wing. 

     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam:  Sir, I was in particular referring to a specialised kind of rehabilitation programme, because there are quite a number of offenders.  Is there a need and, if so, would the Ministry consider bringing in some expertise in that regard?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:  We can consider that.  The Prisons Department is always willing to try new programmes but, like I have said, there is already an outreach to them under this general 3R programme.

SMOKING IN PUBS

(Banning)

     2.  Mdm Cynthia Phua asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources whether the Government will consider banning smoking in pubs.

     The Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government regularly reviews the list of places where smoking is prohibited. The National Environment Agency (NEA) is currently reviewing the list of places which are not covered under the current smoking ban. These places include not just pubs, but also bus shelters, bus interchanges, public toilets, hawker centres and coffeeshops. Some members of the public have given feedback on banning smoking in places like pubs, hawker centres and coffeeshops. NEA will be studying the issues carefully, and conduct consultation with the public and businesses before a decision is made.   

 

 

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar):  Sir, may I ask the Minister whether it is correct that studies have shown that smoking in the smoke of others increases the risk of lung cancer by 20-30% and heart diseases by 25-30%?  Is it not a fact that environmental tobacco smoke contains approximately 4,000 chemicals that cause health hazard.  Has there been measurement done on the environmental tobacco smoke level in our pubs here?  Should the Minister endeavour to better protect the health of non-smokers in public places?  Should he not highlight to businessmen on the successful experiences of other countries and smoke-free pubs, especially those that have managed to attract more non-smoking customers that loathe the stink of nicotine and health hazards?

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, I cannot confirm the figures mentioned by the Member but the point that she is making, which is widely accepted by the health community, is that passive smoking does increase the risk of getting diseases such as cancer.

 

     On the point as to whether or not we should protect non-smokers, I agree entirely with her that we should protect non-smokers and that is why we are reviewing the places which are not covered under the current smoking ban.  But we will also have to bear in mind that we have to consult widely both the public and the businesses.  That is why I mentioned in my reply earlier that the businesses will be consulted because they also have to be made to understand that if we move, this should not affect them adversely but, at the same time, we want them to be a responsible partner in the move to encourage people not to smoke and take up healthy lifestyles.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua:  Sir, I would urge the Minister to look actively at banning smoking in those places where there are many young children, especially at hawker centres and eating houses.  I am a passive smoker.  My mother has passed away but my father is an active smoker.  It is very easy for a passive smoker to become a smoker because you are used to the smoke.  I would like the Ministry to actively look into banning smoking in such public places.

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  Sir, again, I would like to thank the Member because we do have evidence to show that non-smokers, who are exposed to the smoking environment, will eventually  pick up the smoking habit and this is something that we want to prevent.  As I mentioned in my reply, we will consult and consider all the issues carefully before we move because there are implications.  We will finish the study before we make a decision.

     Dr Lily Neo:  Sir, earlier on, I asked on the environmental tobacco smoke level measurement.  Could the Minister address that question, please?

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  My apologies, Sir.  I do not have the answer to that.  Let me check whether we have done the test or not.  This is something that is done jointly by my Ministry together with the Ministry of Health. I will check and if the information is available, I will pass it on to the Member.

Column No : 1247

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS

(Retrofitting exercise for better design clothes drying system)

     3.  Mr Zainudin Nordin asked the Minister for National Development with the existence of newer and better design clothes drying racks fitted to the new and upgraded HDB flats, will HDB consider carrying out a one-time retrofitting exercise for flats fitted with the older design drying racks.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng) (for the Minister for National Development):   Sir, the pipe socket clothes drying system has been in use in HDB flats since the 1960s.  The pipe sockets are used to hold bamboo poles for hanging of clothes outside the kitchen area.

 

     With changes in flat design, HDB introduced the recessed clothes drying system in 1995.  Under this system, both ends of the bamboo poles are supported by clothes drying racks installed at the service balcony/kitchen on one side, and the concrete ledge outside the bedroom on the other side.  As the poles are supported at both ends, they are more stable and make for easier hanging of clothes for residents.

 

     Both types of clothes drying systems are safe so long as residents are careful when hanging out their clothes.  It is therefore not necessary for HDB to carry out a one-time retrofitting exercise for all the flats fitted with the pipe socket clothes drying system.   However, as and when the flats undergo upgrading, the recessed clothes drying system can be provided as long as the flat configuration allows for it.

 

     HDB is always looking for more innovative systems to serve residents better.  HDB has piloted a new parallel clothes drying rack system in new flats.  If successful, HDB will install the system in all its new flats.  

 

     Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh):  Sir, we are aware that we have a greying population and I think this problem will become more acute as time goes by.  May I know what kind of timeframe the Ministry is looking at to make improvements to the existing old system?

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng:  Sir, the pilot project is currently implemented in two areas in Queenstown and Toa Payoh.  Once we have gotten the feedback from the residents and have reviewed the implementation; if it is successful and accepted, going forward, we will start to use it for all new flats.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua:  Sir, we are talking about old flats and not new flats which will be taken care of.  But we are urging the Minister to look at the older flats because these are where our older residents are living.  This item is included in the Main Upgrading Programme but it is not included in the Interim Upgrading Programme or the Lift Upgrading Programme.  Could the Minister consider, due to our aging population, installing this item under these two programmes?

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng:  Sir, the Lift Upgrading Programme is purely for the purpose of upgrading lifts to serve all floors.  The Interim Upgrading Programme generally looks at the common areas in the precinct.  Therefore, the MUP is the only programme right now that includes the provision of new clothes drying system.

 

     I recognise the fact that our population is aging and there are more elderly people in our midst and especially when HDB builds high-rise buildings, the existing clothes drying system may not be ideal.  But it is safe, if used properly and the cost involved is also not trivial.  Therefore, I think it is prudent for us to adopt new systems as material science improves and new designs come up, and we will do so progressively.

                                                                                                                 


     Mdm Cynthia Phua: Sir, I would like to urge the Minister to reconsider this matter.  Because these clothes drying racks occupy part of the tenant's space.  It is considered as common property.  For the Interim Upgrading Programme, it involves the upgrading of the common environment.  Would the Minister consider including this item into the interim upgrading so that our existing flat owners do not have to wait so long for improvements?

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng: Sir, normally, a working committee will be set up for the Interim Upgrading Programme or the Main Upgrading Programme.  The working committees, at ground level, would make such decisions and trade-offs as to what works they would like to undertake.  I think we will have no objections if the working committee feels that this is an area of work which they would like to undertake in lieu of other works which the budget would allow.

     Mr Wee Siew Kim (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, while we are on the subject of bamboos, can I find out whether there are any safety elements in implementing the new system rather than just focus on cost?

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng: Sir, when we introduced the new system in Queenstown and Toa Payoh, these are posts that are affixed on both ends and parallel to the ledge.  The disadvantage is that you will have to hang your clothes a piece at a time rather than to bring out the entire bamboo pole of clothes at one go.  However, it avoids the need to buy bamboo poles.  So it is a safer system, and safety is indeed a primary consideration.

     Mr Speaker: Mdm Phua, one last question on bamboos.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua: Sir, I want to urge the Minister to consider the matter again because under the Interim Upgrading Programme, this item is not within the guidelines.  If the Minister would say yes, it would be included in the guidelines, then I am very happy.

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng: I think we can consider it.

     Mr Speaker; Mr Zainudin, your next Question, please. 

Column No : 1252

PRE-SCHOOL EDUCATION CENTRE

(Approval process of licence)

     4.  Mr Zainudin Nordin asked the Minister for Education (a) how many applications for pre-school education centre licence has his Ministry received in the last 5 years; (b) what are the criteria for approval of the licence;   (c) what other Government agencies are involved in the approval process;  and  (d) whether these agencies work closely on such approvals or do they merely focus on their respective areas of concern.

     The Minister of State for Education (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1999, five years ago, MOE has registered 99 pre-school education centres or kindergartens. MOE registers kindergartens if they meet the basic requirements in land use, safety, hygiene, teacher qualifications and curriculum.

 

      Potential operators would need to obtain clearances from the relevant authorities before applying for registration with the Ministry of Education. To start with, they must obtain legal status for their kindergartens. Hence, those that are commercially run would, first, have to register the businesses with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA). Those that are community-based must ensure their parent organisations have been registered with the Registry of Societies.

 

      Like all businesses and societies, the kindergartens would have to seek planning approval from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) for land use as a kindergarten, from the Fire Safety and Shelter Department (FSSD) for fire safety compliance, and from the Land Transport Authority (LTA) for traffic and parking clearance. For rebuilding or extensive alteration of premises, approval from the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) is also required.

 

      However, for the Housing Development Board (HDB) owned premises, potential operators can obtain all the clearances for the premises through the HDB.

 

      MOE would assess the suitability of the curriculum and teacher qualifications before granting registration. During the approval process, the relevant authorities consult with one another where necessary. 

 

      From 30th August of this year, applicants can apply for multiple licences using one Government portal, ie, Online Businesses Licensing Service (OBLS) which Members can reach at http://licences.business.gov.sg to obtain clearances from the relevant agencies, and wait for outcomes given by respective agencies. Hence, potential operators can apply for the registration of kindergartens through OBLS. The one-stop portal enables applicants to identify the clearances needed to start a kindergarten and to apply for clearances simultaneously for the proposed premises. To date, since the end of August this year, the Ministry of Education has received five applications through OBLS.

 

                 

     Mr Zainudin Nordin: Sir, may I know, on the average, how long is the process, from the point when a company applies for a licence to the point when the licence is awarded?

     Mr Chan Soo Sen: Of course, it depends on specific cases.  Before OBLS, on the average, it takes about four weeks.  After OBLS, on the average, it takes about two weeks.

REVISED CHINESE LANGUAGE CURRICULUM

1.52 pm

     The Minister for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

 

          "That this House endorses the Report of the Chinese Language Curriculum and Pedagogy Review Committee, contained in Paper Cmd 9 of 2004, and supports a revised Chinese Language (CL) curriculum to: (1) enthuse all CL students and develop in them an abiding interest in the language and culture; (2) provide greater customisation and flexibility at the primary level; (3) place greater emphasis on oral fluency and reading for the majority of the students, and for those with the ability and interest, to develop stronger competence and understanding of the Chinese language and culture."

The Review Process

     Members have copies of the White Paper. I will highlight the key considerations that went into this review, and the thinking behind the fundamental changes that are being recommended to the way the Chinese Language is taught and learnt.

            Let me first say something about the process by which the recommended changes were arrived at. The Committee was headed by  Mr Wee Heng Tin, our former Director-General of Education. Its members were mainly comprised of professional educators - school principals, academics, and heads of  mother tongue language departments. They came with extensive experience in our bilingual education system.  The educationists on the Committee have each had  an average of 25 years in the field. Eight of the 12 members have also been Chinese Language educators either now or at some point in their careers.

     The Committee consulted widely, with all our stakeholders in Chinese Language learning, including teachers and students, parents, Chinese community organisations and the media.  They held 19 dialogue sessions and visited 13 schools to observe the  learning of Chinese Language as it is today.  MOE also conducted a comprehensive survey of Chinese Language teaching and learning, involving about 10,000 students, parents, teachers and principals.  In all, the recommendations took nine months to be shaped. My Ministry could not have asked for a more thorough and informed review by a more credible team.

Flexibility and Enjoyment

     There is no lack of interest in the Chinese Language in Singapore. MOE's survey of students and parents found that the vast majority recognise the importance of learning the Chinese Language. Among English-speaking homes, 92% of parents feel it is important for their child to learn the Chinese Language. The interest in learning Chinese Language is founded on a desire to retain a sense of identity, as well as the increasing spur of economic opportunities in China.  But whether the reasons are cultural or pragmatic, they provide a strong foundation going forward for the learning of Chinese Language in our schools.

         We are not therefore crafting changes to the Chinese Language curriculum to cater to the needs of a minority with a disinterest in the language. We are seeking to help the majority of Chinese students who, regardless of home backgrounds, want to learn their mother tongue  as best they can, as part of the education they receive in school. We want them to be enthused by the language, find it relevant in their lives as they grow up,  learn it to the highest level they are capable of in school, and want to keep up with the language well after they leave.

     If I were to sum up the Committee's recommendations, it would be in two words  -  flexibility and enjoyment.

           First, we have to recognise the fundamental shifts that have taken place in our social landscape.  The majority of those entering Primary 1 today use English as their main language, both at home and amongst their friends and classmates.  Teachers tell us that the shift in these new cohorts is striking, even compared to today's Primary 6 cohort; in other words, the shift from today's Primary 6 cohort to today's Primary 1 cohort is a significant one.

     We have to regear our approaches to teaching Chinese Language to meet the needs of this new generation of Singaporeans, and future generations after them. The bilingual approach to teaching Chinese Language that we have introduced in the early primary years (Primary 1 and 2), starting with four schools in 2002 and another seven this year, was the first step. But it did not involve any change in curriculum, only selective change in teaching methods. We have to go beyond this. We must have a curriculum that is itself flexible, and tailored to the student's level of competence at the very outset. This is what the modular approach advocated by the Committee seeks to do. Some students will need more time, and a curriculum that helps them build confidence in a language that they have had little exposure to at home.  Others can move faster and go further, and some will be encouraged in later years to immerse themselves more deeply in the language and culture.  That is the flexibility.

     The second principle underpinning the changes is the need to make Chinese Language an enjoyable, living language for our students. That has to be the common denominator for all our students, regardless of the path or elective that they choose to take, and regardless of their final level of achievement in learning the language in school.

           As the Committee has observed in its report, while learning the various Chinese Language skills is important, our fundamental objective must be to nurture in our students an abiding interest in the language.

           Not every student will end up working in China or using the Chinese Language to earn a living.  And we cannot tell, when a child is in school, what he will do later in life and where he will end up. But if we can make every student feel engaged in the learning of the Chinese Language, to find it enjoyable and not be turned off by the way we expect him to learn it, we stand the best chance of nurturing a person who will continue to learn the language, take pride in it being his mother tongue, and want to use it after he leaves school. Or be able to brush up his skills when he needs to, for example, if he has to do China business.

Key Changes

     To achieve flexibility and bring greater enjoyment into learning the Chinese Language, the Committee has made wide-ranging recommendations. It requires a total approach, not piecemeal changes. The Committee's report proposes changes in curriculum structures, assessment systems, teaching methods, textbooks and other instructional materials, and the greater use of technology. It recommends the creative use of the informal curriculum in schools, and ways for MOE to boost the quantity and quality of the Chinese Language teacher workforce.

It also calls for the support of the whole community, including parents, the newspaper and TV media, and Chinese community organisations.

 

     I will not cover each of these areas in detail. But let me lay out the basic ideas behind the major proposals -  first, the customisation of learning and a modular approach in primary schools; and second, why we should place greater emphasis, for the majority of students, on building up the ability to communicate and read in the Chinese Language.

 

Customisation from Primary One

 

     Today, there is an adequate degree of customisation at the secondary school level.  There are five Chinese Language syllabuses at the secondary level.  A student in the Express stream, for instance, can choose from three syllabuses - Chinese Language, Higher Chinese, or Chinese Language 'B' syllabus.  At the upper primary levels, we have Chinese Language and the Higher Chinese syllabuses, and for the EM3 course, the Basic Chinese syllabus.

 

     But to maximise a child's potential in learning Chinese Language, we need a differentiated approach from the outset, that takes into account the exposure that the child has to the language at home.  The vast majority of Chinese Language teachers, well over 94%, feel this is necessary. We surveyed them. They are on the ground, they know what it takes to motivate and enthuse their pupils.  The vast majority say that we need a differentiated approach from the outset.

 

     The modular approach proposed by the Committee also follows what is generally known about the natural progression in acquiring a language, which begins with developing the ability to listen and speak a language. The bridging and reinforcement modules that will be introduced, aimed at children with little exposure to the Chinese Language, will focus on developing confidence in oral skills early.  Teachers will be trained to identify students who can benefit from these modules, and will advise parents. MOE will make available simple diagnostic tools to help teachers do so.

 

Core Standards

     The Committee proposes however to maintain a common core curriculum for all students, upon which the PSLE assessment for the regular Chinese Language subject will be based. The new core curriculum will take up 70% to 80% of Chinese Language curriculum time. The modular approach being proposed does not therefore mean different end points within the regular Chinese Language curriculum at the primary level. Instead, it seeks to help students who do not have the background in the language by providing bridging and reinforcement modules in the early primary years, so that they can catch up and be better prepared for the new core curriculum. Those with the ability to go faster or further will take enrichment modules, while a significant number are also expected to take Higher Chinese at Primary 5 to 6.

 

     I agree with the Committee's approach of maintaining a common standard during the primary years, that will serve as a foundation for all Chinese Language students. It will motivate all students to achieve this foundation in the language, including those from English-speaking backgrounds. It will be premature to 'stream' these students into a weaker Chinese Language course at the primary school stage, or to lower their expectations too early of what they can achieve with reasonable effort. What we must do, however, is to ensure that the core curriculum is shaped so that the majority of students will find it  achievable and engaging.

 

     Our challenge therefore is to make the learning of Chinese Language enjoyable, without making it unchallenging.  As with the English Language or any other subject of study, students must put in the effort and practice, to achieve real learning and progress. But it should not be tedious effort, with little sense of excitement or gain. We should do all we can to keep students turned on to Chinese Language learning, not turn them off. We will have to design a realistic workload for the majority of students, give them a syllabus that allows them to relate what they learn to their daily lives, and give teachers the flexibility to venture out of the syllabus to make learning stimulating.  

 

Emphasising listening, speaking and reading

 

     This is also the reason for the Committee's second major proposal, which is to shift the balance of emphasis towards communication and reading, for the majority of students.

 

     Ideally, we would want all our Chinese Language students to be fluent in all four language skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing. However, in adult life, the vast majority of Singaporeans will more often hear, speak and read Chinese, than they would need to write Chinese.

 

     We have to be practical about what is achievable for the majority of students, within a broad-based curriculum that has  English as the first language. The majority will spend about 25% of their total curriculum time in their early primary years learning the mother tongue, and 15% of curriculum time in their late primary and secondary years. How do we best motivate them to want to use the language spontaneously, and learn it not just for their examinations but because they have an intrinsic interest in the language and feel that it is part of a living culture for them?

 

     The Committee recommends that the best approach for the majority of students is to focus, first and foremost, on listening, speaking and reading the language. It is hoped that this will encourage them to converse using the Chinese Language, read stories that appeal to their imagination, and by seeing the benefits of using the language more frequently in these ways, that they will want to learn the language further.  In other words, to develop the intrinsic motivation to learn the language.

 

     To achieve greater fluency in listening, speaking and reading, we have to make space in the curriculum. To do this, the Committee recommends altering the curriculum and examinations to reduce the current heavy emphasis on character stroke memorisation; removing less frequently used characters from the syllabus; and reducing the number of passages that have to be taught from the textbooks.  It does not recommend abandoning writing skills, but using it to reinforce the other language skills. Teachers should be encouraged to let students discover the art and beauty in the writing of the Chinese Language script  -  as many teachers already do.

 

     We will experiment with new approaches to teaching.  MOE will conduct a pilot study with some schools of new approaches that help students to read more in the early primary years, and to focus less on script-writing. We will study the feasibility of this approach, and whether it  leads to children developing a greater competence and interest in the language.  This has to be piloted.

 

Focus on learning outcomes

 

     MOE will also study carefully the standards that students should be expected to achieve in primary and secondary schools for each of the four language skills. The Committee recommends focusing, first, on qualitative outcomes of Chinese Language learning at each stage, say at Primary 6 and Secondary 4, rather than fixing or predetermining the number of characters that a pupil should learn to read or write.  The size of a child's vocabulary is one way of measuring a child's language ability.  But of much greater significance is how confidently and appropriately the child can actually use and manipulate the vocabulary that he has learned.

 

     So by the end of Secondary 4, for example, the Committee recommends that students be able to read and appreciate poems and short stories, and read most articles in local newspapers and magazines.  They should be able to understand local news reports, and deliver, with some preparation, coherent views on local news reports, and other topics of interest in front of an audience; and compose a 250-300 word narrative or expository essay with the help of a dictionary and/or assistive computer tools.

     MOE agrees broadly with this approach.  We will work out  the number of characters and words that students need to learn in order to achieve these learning outcomes  -  such as is required to comprehend daily news articles. For example, according to Singapore Press Holdings' Chinese Language Consultant Wang Huidi, knowing about 1,800 characters would provide 98% reading coverage of Zaobao. About 1,300 most-frequently used characters will give 95% of reading coverage.

     But, as recommended by the Committee, we will move away from hard and fast rules on the number of characters and phrases that students should read or write. We will  focus instead on achieving  useful learning outcomes. We will keep an open mind, and adjust the syllabus requirements as we learn from experience on the ground.  Our objective will be to ensure that students retain what they learn, and are able to use the vocabulary they learn in new contexts -  not just be able to recall from a prescribed list of characters and phrases for the purpose of their examinations.   How we assess our students will be adjusted to match this objective. 

     Further, as recommended by the Committee, MOE will also review the role of the character list that underpins the production of instructional materials, teaching practice and assessment. While the character list is useful in allowing teachers to know that they have adequately covered the requirements of the syllabus, it has tended to steer teaching and learning towards drilling in a prescribed list of characters. MOE will study how best we can provide teachers with some guide, while encouraging them to incorporate engaging materials and use their own methods to  liven up learning.

 

     To sum up this point, our objective will be to provide students with the room to use and practise what they have learned, so as to develop confidence and competence in the language. MOE will work out how to avoid overloading the syllabus so that we provide enough space and time in the curriculum for teachers and students to achieve this. Our Chinese Language Heads of Department point out that the current syllabus provides little room for this. Too much volume, leading to teachers rushing to complete the syllabus, as each chapter contains new or additional words and phrases that have to be mastered. They tell us students do not have time to use and practise what they learn. The Heads of Department and teachers have their own war stories. One that many recall was of a recent PSLE examination that tested the Primary 6 students on some characters that they had learnt in Primary 4. The students were stumped. They had forgotten what they had learned just two years earlier, because both teachers and students were focused on covering the Primary 5 and 6 syllabus, which was itself a demanding load. 


     Teachers therefore feel that there is some trade-off between volume and the quality of learning outcomes.  MOE will focus on these learning outcomes as we review the curriculum. We will set realistic targets that the majority of students can achieve, provide room for innovative teaching practices and school-designed curricula, and for teachers to venture out of the regular syllabus. And we will always ask ourselves what we hope our students can do with the vocabulary and language skills that they have learned.

 

Encouraging excellence

 

     The Committee also recommends encouraging students with the ability and interest to develop competence in all four language skills, and obtain a good understanding of Chinese history and culture, through the Higher Chinese curriculum.

 

     This is an important part of the flexible curriculum strategy that MOE has taken. Higher Chinese forms the base in our efforts to provide opportunities for students with the ability to engage in deeper study of the language and culture. In January this year, as Members know, we relaxed the criteria required for students to opt for Higher Chinese in primary and secondary schools. Since the change, we have had about 25% more Secondary 1 students choosing to take Higher Chinese. MOE will post more teachers to schools where there is a critical mass of students who offer Higher Chinese, to make the study of the subject more convenient.  This will be one of our priorities over the next few years, as we build up our teaching force.


     Building on Higher Chinese, we are encouraging our secondary schools to enhance the Chinese Language learning environment by offering new Chinese Language-based subjects, such as Chinese Culture and Thought and Literature in Chinese as a Combined Humanities elective; Literature in Chinese is already a full subject, and we are going to allow it to be used as an elective for the Combined Humanities subject.  We are extending the Language Elective Programme to a fourth Junior College from 2006, and rolling out the Bicultural Studies Programme next year. 

 

    At the other end of the spectrum, we must continue to address the needs of those who struggle with Chinese Language in secondary schools despite putting in reasonable effort.  The Chinese Language 'B' syllabus was put in place in 2001 from Secondary 3 for this purpose.  In January this year, apart from relaxing the criteria for students to take Higher Chinese, we also opened the Chinese Language 'B' option from Secondary 1.

Pre-school

 

     MOE will also work with the pre-school sector to support the objectives of the Chinese Language review. We will collaborate with them in developing a curriculum framework for Chinese Language learning in the early childhood years that makes learning fun and allows children to gain confidence. This will be particularly helpful for children who get limited home exposure to the Chinese Language. By creating natural situations for preschoolers to build up their listening and speaking skills, the sector can prepare them well for the revised curriculum and teaching approaches at the primary school level in future. 

 

ML and TL review

 

      We will also review the learning of Malay Language (ML) and Tamil Language (TL) in our schools. This year, 58% of our Indian Primary 1 students came from homes that spoke predominantly English.  The initial feedback

from Tamil parents suggests that the issues facing Tamil Language students are fundamentally not different from those encountered in learning the Chinese Language. For Malay Language students, the issues are less severe. The Malay Language shares the same script as the English Language. The majority of Malay students entering Primary 1 still use Malay Language as their dominant home language, with just 22% using the English Language.  However, among Primary 1 Malay Language students with at least one parent having a university qualification, the proportion using predominantly English at home is much higher, close to 60%.

 

     MOE will set up two high level committees to review the Malay Language and Tamil Language curriculum respectively.  The composition of these committees will be announced in early December.  Work should start in January next year, and we expect to complete the two reviews around August 2005.

 

Bilingual policy

 

       Sir, the changes we will make to the Chinese Language curriculum are part of how we make sure bilingualism thrives in Singapore.  We cannot let new generations of Singaporeans gradually lose their competence in their mother tongues, or lose their instinctive sense of identity with the cultures that the Mother Tongue Languages represent.

 

       Our English-speaking capability, combined with our competence and feel for the Mother Tongue Languages, is our source of competitive edge, allowing us to stay relevant to both Asia and the West.

 

      And beyond this, our Mother Tongue Languages will always be essential to give us our identity.  Our cultures, languages, and values give us roots, a quiet confidence in who we are. Keeping our Mother Tongue Languages and cultures will give each new generation of Singaporeans a sense of connectedness and resilience.

 

     This is why our bilingual policy remains a key feature of our education system, and why we now have to regear and adapt our strategies to make sure it succeeds.

 

Implementing the changes well

 

      I have described the key thrusts of the proposed changes to the Chinese Language curriculum. Success in these changes will lie in thorough and well-coordinated implementation in all areas, from curriculum design to teacher training and the development of instructional materials.  This will be a major priority for the Ministry of Education in the next five years. We will dedicate the necessary resources to achieve the objectives set out in the White Paper.

 

     The most critical factor to the success of the reforms will be our Chinese Language teachers. They are also our best asset. The majority are keen on change, and many are already putting into practice new strategies to help their pupils develop a love for the language. And there are numerous examples on the ground, of teachers who inspire their students to love the language, including classes or students who would normally be considered weak in the language. So we will focus above all on helping our teachers, on preparing them to implement the changes that are to come with vigour and imagination. We will provide teachers more space, through our syllabus and examination reforms, to bring in new teaching techniques.  MOE will work to recruit more teachers, from both local and foreign sources, without diminishing the quality of recruits. We will also invest more in training both new and current Chinese Language teachers, to ensure that they are confident in delivering a new, more flexible curriculum.

 

      Mr Wee Heng Tin will chair a steering committee to oversee the Ministry of Education's implementation of the White Paper's recommendations, which include the curriculum development, research and testing of new teaching and assessment techniques, and ways to develop the teaching force.  MOS Chan Soo Sen will serve as Adviser of that committee.

 

      MOS Chan will also head another committee, a community taskforce that will set out to garner the support of the Chinese community for these changes, and to facilitate a continuing process of collaboration between our schools, parents, community organisations and the media.  When parents got together to organise a Mid-Autumn Festival at Chua Chu Kang Primary School, 1,500 people turned up. We will need the support of our community organisations, industry partners and the media as we seek to develop new learning materials, songs and resources, as well as providing opportunities and platforms outside the school for our young to enjoy using the language.

 

      Whether in school or in the community, we want the Chinese Language to come alive. Whether high-brow or low-brow, we have to find every way to make the Chinese Language fun for our children, as with the other mother tongues. For example, all of us who have children learning the Chinese Language know the emerging power of Asian pop culture.  When Jurong Junior College got its JC1 students involved in Chinese pop culture recently, the students were enthralled. When zbNOW,  the Lifestyle section of Zaobao, recently launched a song as part of its  Popcorn programme, it was tremendously popular in schools. And that is also why the third-last round of Singapore Idol, which required Taufik, Sylvester, Olinda and Daphne to sing Asian pop songs, had a special endearing quality.  And when Olinda dedicated Teresa Teng's Endless Stream Of Words or Qian Yan Wan Yu to her grandmother, everyone felt the emotion.

Problems in learning Chinese

it would be difficult for them to excel in the subject.  It is therefore crucial to help our students develop and retain a healthy interest in the Chinese Language.

The Committee's proposals
 
     In recognition of these challenges, the Committee has made proposals to recalibrate our education system to adapt to the new landscape.  The two main proposals are to adopt:

 

     (a)  A modular approach to the teaching of the Chinese Language to suit the ability of the children; and

 

     (b)  A "Recognise First, Write Later" approach to the teaching of Chinese Language so as to create and sustain children's interest in the language.

 

     Sir, few can argue with the concept and the principles of these recommendations as the Committee has done a very thorough job.  Most feedback I received is supportive of these new approaches.  However, as the proposed changes are fundamental and impacting, there are invariably some concerns from different stakeholders.  I would like to share some of these concerns, and I hope that the Minister would consider and address them.

 

Lowering standard


     First, there is some concern among the Chinese language professionals that the proposed changes will result in further decline in the standard of the language.  They perceive these changes as a compromise solution to ease the pressure on our children.  Are we in reality adjusting our standard to the lowest denominator?  If so, then the question is whether this will be the start of a vicious circle and the standard will continue to slide as time goes on.  Their concern is understandable, given that they have invested much of their life to promote the Chinese Language.

 

     While I am Chinese educated too, I take a slightly different view.  I believe that, firstly, the decline in the overall Chinese standard among Singaporean students is more a result of the changed environment.  If we do not change our teaching programme and instead continue to make Chinese learning a painful and stressful experience in the initial years of primary education, our children will lose interest in the subject and they will discard the language as soon as they leave school.  Over time, the real standard of the language could slide even faster.   I agree with the Committee that by making the initial learning process more interesting and more pleasant, we can hope to retain our children's interest in the subject at least a while longer and, hopefully, they will be able to learn and retain more of what they learn.  This perhaps is the one aspect of "teach less, learn more".

 

     What is more important, perhaps, is to ensure that there are sufficient avenues to allow those who are talented and have a special interest in the language to pursue their studies further.  We could create more opportunities for those who want to pursue Chinese Language to a much higher standard to do so.  For example, students who are in the polytechnics because they could not qualify for university admission could be offered special courses in the Chinese Language in the university or NIE which may eventually lead to a diploma or degree.  This will allow more peaks of excellence in the Chinese Language to emerge and average up the standard of the language here.

 

     We may need to explain this more clearly to the Chinese community to address their concern about the standard of the language falling as a result of the changes in the education policy.  This will help harness their support for our policy.

 

Some basic writing skill is still needed


     Second, while I agree that the requirement to learn complex writing skills should be deferred, I think students should still learn the basic strokes and simple characters at an early stage.  These basic strokes are like the radicals of the Chinese characters.  They are like alphabets in English, and they are the basic components of Chinese characters.  They are essential in helping students recognise words.  Without a good familiarity with them, it would be difficult for students to recognise and retain Chinese characters.  Some writing will also help students internalise the language and reinforce their reading skill.

 

     Therefore, I would like to urge the Ministry to consider retaining some basic writing skills even in the lower primary classes, but it probably would not be necessary to test these skills in the examinations.

 

Selection process of the modular system


     Third, I would like to touch on the selection process in the modular system.  While the modular approach to teaching Chinese will allow students of varying abilities to progress at their own pace, such an approach will involve a selection process.  The proposal calls for a Core Module for all students in the primary schools.  The weaker ones will take up the Bridging or Reinforcement Module while the stronger students will pursue the Enrichment Module.  The question is: what is the basis of determining the ability of the students entering Primary 1, so as to decide which module they should take up?  Will they be put through a test?  Will it be purely based on the language background of the student's family?

Teaching/reading materials must be improved


     Fifth, we must improve our textbook and reading materials.  According to the MOE survey, one of the top reasons cited by students who liked Chinese is that they find the Chinese textbook interesting.  Therefore, it is important for us to continue to improve the content of our textbooks to make it even more interesting and engaging.  I hope the Ministry will put in resources in this area.

 

     What I find lacking though are good, interesting and captivating reading materials outside the school.  Our bookstores here carry quite a lot of Chinese books, but a large proportion of them are translated materials from western literature.  Most original Chinese books circle around a handful of legends, such as the Three Kingdoms, Water Margin, Journey to the West, and Dreams of the Red Chamber, and so on.  In fact, there are many versions of them.  Maybe it is a commercial consequence, as the market here for Chinese books is much smaller than that for English ones.  But we must break this vicious circle.  While we empower our children to read, we must also ensure that there are abundant supplies of reading materials that will interest them.

 

     Perhaps the Ministry could consider various alternatives.  For example, we can bring in better reading materials from China or Taiwan directly and make them available for students and parents, or put them in the school libraries so that students can have easy access to them.  As a last resort, we could also develop such materials ourselves in collaboration with other agencies.

 

Creating opportunities to use the language


     Sixth, while we improve the teaching of the Chinese Language, we must also look into ways to create more opportunities to use the language in schools and in the communities.  This will go a long way towards keeping the language alive and making its learning a living experience rather than a dry and boring process.

 

     Some have suggested that a day in the week be designated as "Speak Mandarin Day" in the schools.  I am not so sure this would be effective.  Other than the difficulties in communicating with other races who do not speak Mandarin, an artificially created environment is unreal and difficult to sustain.  

 

     We could introduce more immersion courses or exchange programmes to allow more students to spend, say, a month, in China and this will undoubtedly improve their grasp of the language in its natural environment.  Even if their proficiency degrades after they return to Singapore, the immersion experience would have strengthened their foundation permanently.  This is of course costly and needs to be considered carefully.

 

     The Ministry could also encourage schools to introduce a Chinese newsletter where students can contribute their compositions to be published.  It could also include contributions from teachers on tips on Chinese Language, as well as language puzzles and quizzes, to make it interesting.

 

     Occasionally, we could also organise international competitions in Chinese Language, such as debates, theatrical works, choruses, etc, to create opportunities for our students to interact with Chinese Language students from other countries.  This will help level up their standard, help them appreciate the language better and generate greater interest in it.

 

     I believe television programmes could also be one very effective medium to encourage the use of the Chinese Language.  Many children and adults watch our television programmes.  Unfortunately, there is a lack of good Chinese programmes that are suitable for children.  Most of the children channels on the cable are English-based.  The most popular local Chinese programmes tend to be the television serials.  While some children may watch these programmes, they tend to rely on the English subtitles.  Would it not be possible to put in Chinese subtitles in our Chinese serials and even daily news?  This would not only help our viewers improve their listening skills, but will also help improve their ability to recognise Chinese characters when they look at the screen.  Of course, there are commercial implications that have to be considered.

 

We need parents' support


     Seventh, we need to gain support from the parents.  Parents play an important part in the success of these changes too.  A recent survey by the Feedback Unit indicates that only 50% of the parents feel that our education system is developing our students to their fullest potential, and only 26% of parents are aware of the desired outcome of our education system.  As it is, some parents are already quite confused with the changes in the education landscape over the last few years.  These proposed changes in the Chinese Language programme will undoubtedly add to their confusion and anxiety.

 

     However, education is a partnership among the Government, students and parents.  If the parents are out of sync with the education policy, we will have a missing link.  We must, therefore, take pains to explain our policy changes to the affected parents, so that they will buy into our new approach and become effective partners in our education programme.  I hope that when the changes are implemented, the Ministry could produce information memos to explain the impact of these changes and help parents to adapt to the new system.

 

     Parents must also take a positive approach and play a supporting role in their children's education.  It is also important for our parents to have realistic expectations of their children.  It is natural for parents to wan zi cheng long, ie, expect their children to become a dragon.  However, unrealistic expectation will result in unwarranted frustration and demoralisation.  While it is good to set a higher target so that our children will be motivated to strive for better performance, we must not be critical or discouraging when they could not achieve the goals we set.  Parents must strike a balance between motivating our children and stressing them.  This way, learning will be a more pleasant and enriching experience for our children.


Teachers' readiness


     Conceptually, the proposed approach to Chinese Language teaching is in the right direction.  However, its success depends to a very large extent on the implementation which, in turn, depends critically on the schools and the teachers who will deliver the syllabus.  We need to address

three issues with regard to the Chinese Language teachers:

 

     Firstly, are the teachers convinced that the new approach is a better approach? 

 

     Secondly, will the teachers be ready to adopt the system? 

 

     Thirdly, how do we maintain and improve the quality and quantity of our Chinese language teachers?

 

     I am glad that the Committee has consulted the teachers and principals widely before finalising its recommendations.  However, we cannot take it for granted that all teachers will embrace the new approach wholeheartedly.  Many of them have been brought up under the old system and they believe in that system absolutely.  It is therefore important for the supervisors and principals to spend time and effort to explain these changes to our teachers to ensure that they too are convinced.

 

      Having been convinced, it will need time for the teachers to get familiar with the new approach and be trained to deliver the new syllabus.  New teachers joining the service should also be put on a new Chinese programme at the NIE to ensure they are well prepared for the new system when they enter into the service.  I would urge the Ministry to work closely with NIE to work out the detailed training and retraining programmes for our Chinese Language teachers to prepare them well.

 

     There is also some concern about the quality of our Chinese Language teachers.  The general decline in the standard of Chinese language in our schools also means that the quality of the intake pool of Chinese teachers will suffer.  If the quality of our Chinese teachers is limited by the quality of the intake, then we will get caught in yet another vicious circle.  Perhaps we could review the intake system for Chinese Language teachers to ensure the quality can be maintained and improved.  One way is to recruit directly from the A-level students.  We could identify early A-level students who are interested in the Chinese teaching career.  We can offer them teaching scholarships and tailor special preparatory courses for them, some of these could even be conducted at the NIE.  They could be offered guaranteed places in the NIE as a teaching career, skipping the A-level examinations, similar to the new IP programme. This will help improve the recruitment of quality teachers.

 

       It may also be useful for NIE to tie up with leading universities and institutions in China to allow our teachers to go through an immersion programme in China.  For example, they could spend their final year in a Chinese university.

 

Timing

 

      Ninth, this is with regard to timing.  The Minister indicated earlier that the proposed changes will first be tried out on a pilot project in selected schools.  It will be fully implemented in 2008 and the examination system will be in place by 2010.  It seems a long way to go.  I can understand that we need time to iron out the implementation details and to prepare our schools and teachers for these sweeping changes.  However, some parents whose children are in the primary school today will be concerned that their children will not benefit from the new system.  Worse still, some are concerned that the transition period may be unsettling for their children and will affect their final results. 

 

     Perhaps the Ministry can explain clearer the transition arrangement and the effects on the children.  This will help assure affected parents that their children's performance and their future will not suffer as a result of the transition.

 

    Tenth, communication.  Equally important, Sir, is the communication process.  To ensure buy-in by the stakeholders and avoid unnecessary misunderstanding, we have to communicate clearly our intention, help them understand the process and the implications, address their specific concerns and take into account their feedback and suggestions.  This way, we will be able to rally support from all the stakeholders to ensure a smooth implementation.

 

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in conclusion, the proposals put forward by the Committee are one giant step in the right direction.  To help our children acquire a reasonable level of proficiency in the Chinese Language, we must fine-tune our Chinese Language programme to achieve three objectives: 

 

     Firstly, we must create in our children a sustainable interest in the language;

 

     Secondly, we must strengthen their confidence in acquiring and using the language; and

 

     Thirdly, we must motivate them to strive to realise their maximum potential.

 

     As the Minister has said, the success of the proposed changes, however, depends on the implementation process.  For this reason, we must prepare all the stakeholders, including the teachers, the students and the parents, so that they are ready for the changes and we are able to reap maximum benefit from it.

 

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, it was reported in yesterday's Straits Times, quoting MP Mr Gan Kim Yong that "Many in the Chinese community are worried that the standard of Chinese might be lowered".  I suppose as a result of the implementation of the White Paper on the Chinese Language, I also have that same fear.

 

     Chinese and other foreign languages, Science and Mathematics are all considered "hard" subjects in schools. The American schools, in those days, were producing children who were literally illiterates.  After leaving school, these children could hardly read or write.  The lesson from the failed American experiment is that there is no easy route to teach students to master a language or, for that matter, any other subject.  The enthusiastic cooperation of all Chinese Language teachers should be a great help in the teaching of the language. Without the full support of all Chinese Language teachers, the teaching of the Chinese Language in our schools cannot succeed. 

 

    The doing away of Chinese Language as a compulsory subject for entrance to our local universities has great adverse effects on teachers teaching the Chinese language in our schools.  Once the Chinese Language is taken off as a compulsory subject for entrance to local universities, its importance is downgraded.  The standing of Chinese Language teachers in the schools is also lowered.  Chinese Language teachers, as a result, feel very demoralised.  I think that their morale should be restored.  This can be done by changing the policy and once more make Chinese a compulsory subject for entrance to local universities and, at the same time, help to keep the standard of Chinese up in our schools.

 

    Of course, some parents would feel very unhappy.  They would complain, "Why should our children be kept out of the local universities just because they cannot pass their Chinese?"  For such cases, I would say, "Make the students stay one year back and master their Chinese Language".  I am certain that after staying back one year, every JC student, worth his salt, can get a credit in the Chinese Language.  The sacrifice of one year in the life of a student is really nothing and parents should not complain too much about it.  Think of the consequences.  If parents do not support the compulsory passing of the Chinese Language to gain entry into the local university, it may mean the failure of the bilingual policy and the ultimate loss of our mother tongue as a second language.

 

    I support the bilingual policy.  I accept English as a working language in Singapore and, at the same time, accept that each ethnic group should study its own mother tongue.  We are Asians and we should study our own language, other than the English Language, so that we can identify ourselves and be confident of who we really are. 

 

    But in the Singapore context, however, the reality is that we are an open cosmopolitan country with massive influences from the West.  Our markets are flooded with Western goods, books, magazines, films on television and in the theatres, music and Western lifestyles.  We are bombarded unabated with Western influences all the time.  No wonder our people are succumbing to Western influence.  For example, spoken English has increased among Primary One students.  The number of Chinese students entering Primary One who speak predominantly English Language at home has risen from 36% in 1994 to 50% this year, a 14% jump in 10 years.  I hope Singapore can resist populist demands and hold firm its bilingual policy and take all steps to make it work.
