     I would like to share a joke with you and think over some profound meanings behind it.  At a dinner with some Shanghai counterparts, a Singaporean was boasting that he was going to invest S$5 million to develop a piece of land in Pudong, Shanghai.  A Chinese businessman at the table shook his head, chewed on his sesame biscuit nonchalantly and said, "zhima luidou!" (literally: sesame and green bean). On hearing that, our Singaporean businessman responded, "Oh, zhima (sesame), very delicious!". The Singaporean did not know that this Chinese man was actually laughing at him.  Zhima luidou in Chinese simply means "chicken feed or no big deal!". He knew the language but did not appreciate the intricacies behind it.

 

     In Sunzi's Art of War, Sunzi Bingfa,  there is "Zhi ji zhi bi, bai zhan budai" (Know your enemy as you know yourself, then you can fight a hundred battles with no fear of defeat). We should better understand a language and its culture if we want to seize the opportunities of Asian economic development, derive the economic benefits, and maintain the dignity of our nation. Therefore, Singapore must always maintain our competitive edge by being bilingual and bicultural.

 

      At present, our bilingual advantage is challenged: the lack of mother tongue speaking environment, shortage of mother tongue language teachers, outdated teaching methods, and the impact of the western cultures and values... these challenges have affected the enthusiasm of our students in the learning of the mother tongue language and culture.  These challenges are similarly faced by our Malay and Indian population as well. Hence, the proposed reform of the teaching of our mother tongue is urgent.  These recommendations in the White Paper will help keep pace with demands of the times. Some recommendations are also applicable to the teaching of Malay and Tamil mother tongue languages.  Obviously, any good recommendations would have to be accompanied by proper and strategic implementation, before we can see the desired results.

      Some of the proposed changes are revolutionary and some people are worried that the changes may result in a lowering of the standard of mother tongue. I would like to give my views on two aspects. First, some technical factors (relating to teaching methods) that impact the success of the proposed changes, and second, the implications of bilingualism to our culture and social values. 

 

       First of all, learning mother language must be continuous and consistent.  There is a fable about a little bear picking up maize in the field.  The moment he picked up a new one, he would throw away the old one.  After a hard day's work, he went home with just one piece of maize in his hand.  This moral of the story is that continuity and consistency is crucial in our mother tongue language learning process. Will our students learn new things but forget what they have learned in the past, leading to a lowering of linguistic standards?  How can we help those who are interested in the subject matter to keep up with or even pursue the use of their mother tongue?  Like myself, I have not been using Chinese actively for the past 17 years.  It is regrettable that I have lost many of the Chinese words and phrases that I have learned before.  Hence a systematic pedagogy is critical to building and sustaining the students' interest in the language.

      Secondly, students need a solid foundation in learning a language. China implemented the  "Recognise first, Write later" method of teaching Chinese language, which worked well. In comparison, the Chinese students have an overall, ie, 100% Chinese learning environment.  But in Singapore, only 50% of our students may speak Mandarin at home.  There are also few public signages in Mandarin, contributing to the lack of an overall learning environment. As such, the four basic skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing will continue to be critical in learning a language.  With the reforms to make language learning easier, should students continue to leverage on such traditional techniques as repeatedly reviewing the Chinese words and mastering it through constant exposure? In the education reforms to 'teach less, learn more', we must avoid giving students the wrong impression that the Chinese characters are so simple that we do not need to learn to write them, and that we can simply rely on a dictionary or technology like pressing a few buttons on the computer or SMS to recall all the Chinese words. Students should be given a solid foundation in the learning of the Chinese alphabets/characters. To this end, both teachers and students should make joint efforts in having a deeper understanding of the language. Take teaching homonymic characters as an example: the pronunciation  nao  in  fan nao (vexed or worried)  and tou  nao (brain) are different.  If the teacher points out that fan nao refers to issues of the heart while tou nao refers to the brain, then it is obvious that the nao in "fun nao" goes with xin (heart) radical  while the nao in "tou nao" follows rou (flesh or human organ) radical. This way, students can quickly grasp the origins and meanings of the characters and simultaneously appreciate the  intricacies of similar words in an interesting way.

      Thirdly, the teaching method should be flexible and state-of-the-art.  A few months ago, when I was in Beijing, I went to a Chinese arts and calligraphy  shop to make four seals.  Given that this is a traditional handicraft, I thought it would take some time before the master craftsman could successfully engrave the intricate designs. But low and behold, the master revealed a computer and a laser printer and to my surprise, created the desired designs on screen and in a few minutes, completed the engravings with the help of hi-technology. The finished products were no less beautiful than handmade works of art. I was enlightened. China, the custodian of an ancient civilisation, has already caught up and embraces modern technology. Why is modern Singapore still clinging onto old methodologies? This experience created a paradigm shift in me. It is time for us to move with the times too. We can explore using technology, computer and IT to help our students with the learning of the Chinese Language so that we can get twice result with half the effort.  We should generate rather than kill the interest of the students if we insist that they just stare at these very dry and boring characters.  In addition, a picture speaks a thousand words. Teaching via pictorial representation of characters (after all, Chinese is a pictorial language) can create visual impact which helps students better learn the language. For example, if we look at a picture of the legend of the eight fairies crossing the sea, each one displaying their extraordinary skills, the visual impact can definitely leave a deeper impression than just eight Chinese characters "ba xian guo hai, ge xian shen tong" do. Hence, I support the use of new technology and methodologies in language teaching. However, I would like to caution that not every student or family can afford such technology, and I would urge the Ministry of Education to pay particular attention to leveling the playing field, look into ways to help those students who could not afford to buy computers, and ensure that these students  are not in any way handicapped. The schools should give them an equal chance of learning. At the same time, we need to ensure that students do not become addicted to the computer and computer games, thereby erode their interest in language books.  

     In addition, bilingual teaching method must be executed appropriately so as to avoid counter-effects. Some students in China use Chinese to learn English inappropriately. For example, for the word "tooth", they would write the Chinese characters du zi (means "abdomen") beside it.  Another example is that the Chinese would normally say, "na li, na li!" to express "don't mention it" when they are praised. Some Chinese students directly translated "na li, na li" to "where, where" based on its literal meaning, causing the foreigner to misinterpret that the Chinese was asking him specifically what he was praising him for! Will our students make similar mistakes?  I once heard a student who translated the English sentence "I want you to look good" as "wo yao ni hao kan!" which in Chinese means, "I will put you on the spot!", which perfectly contradicts his intentions, leading to unnecessary misunderstandings.  These jokes remind us that the teaching pedagogy of language must be apt, and it is necessary to expose students to the language environment so as to gradually reduce the reliance on the English Language crutch to learn Chinese.
     

     Fourthly, the passion and enthusiasm of the institutions, society, teachers and students towards the learning of a mother language is critical to the success of the White Paper. I am glad to learn that 90% of our Chinese students and parents feel that it is important to learn Chinese.  This alone would promote the success of the proposed changes. We should move with the tide and encourage the parents and the students to change their current mindsets in the learning of the mother tongue and culture. Given that the family is the basic learning environment, parents can use Mandarin more often at home, purchase Chinese magazines or software, and encourage their children to read Chinese books and watch Chinese programmes, or even SMS (short message system) in Mandarin. Parents may also learn Chinese together with their children, help each other and through sharing, improve the relationship between the parents and their children. 

     Next, teachers and students should enhance their relationships. To some students, the moment they look at their Chinese teachers, the thought of spelling, dictation and memorising of passages immediately come to mind. Some students even create graffiti of their teachers as ugly figures, to express their unhappiness and fear. If students do not like the teachers, and stay away from the teachers, how can we imagine they would like learning Chinese? This would adversely affect their interests to learn the language and culture. The reverse is also true. Hence it is important for teachers to build a good rapport with their students, thereby influencing their passion in learning. In fact, we have many experienced and passionate Chinese teachers who have spent their entire life teaching the Chinese Language. Many may be retiring or have retired.  The Ministry of Education may consider employing them on a part-time or ad-hoc basis, so that they could continue to contribute in the teaching of the Chinese Language and, at the same time, help to build up a pool of passionate Chinese teachers.
     

     Next, I would like to highlight the "Immersion Programmes" for its effectiveness in building up students' interests in the language and culture.  Many students went to China on immersion courses. It was only after the trips that students learn about traditional items like "barns", "washing tablets", "stone mills" and "spinning wheels", etc. Through exchange and participation with the locals, Singapore students and teachers can better learn the traditions, culture and language, and simultaneously build better rapport. Since we also have a number of Chinese students in Singapore, perhaps we can also organise some sorts of summer camp or learning camp in Singapore, along the lines of  "Singapore - China youths hand in hand toward a prosperous Asia" or "a prosperous future", so that our students and students from China in Singapore can learn from one another. 

     In addition, the Government and the Chinese community should enhance the importance of the bilingual and bicultural talents among us.  "Ren ren wei xian" (ie, meritocracy) is a traditional Confucian value, and is what our society practices. With the emergence of the Chinese economy, bilingual and bicultural talents will gain importance and take on increased roles in our nation's progress. Hence it is urgent for us to cultivate more such talents and accord them their due respect and esteem. A high level, high quality committee comprising the institutions, community and educationists could also be formed to track the timeliness and appropriateness of our policies against the local and overseas trend, as well as feedback from our people on the Chinese pedagogy.

     Now, let me move onto the second part of my speech, on the impact of bilingualism on our culture and values.  What impact would this reform have on our society?  Some people suggest metaphorically that culture is the pillar of a bridge while language is the bridge itself.  If so, let me add that the societal value system and cultural intricacies would be its consequential expressions of art.  This bilingual bridge is thus the link between the (ideas and relationships of) east and the west, and our bilingual policy would be the key to maintain our competitive edge.  Corollary, the government is likened to be the designer of this bridge, while teachers are the architects of human's spirit-all involved in the critical task of building up our bilingual-bicultural talents. Our bilingualism is not merely a tool for economic exchanges, but also is rooted on Singapore's national identity and culture. What kind of impact will the reform bring to our society?  Let us take music as an analogy. We can divide music broadly into two categories: one category refers to the highest echelon of music appreciation - classical music and the operas. It is like the pristine bilingual experts such as the educationists, writers, translators, diplomats, etc, that we want to cultivate. Such talents are the crème de la crème, and are few in numbers. The other category is like popular music - pop or folk songs, and even tunes heard at markets and common places. This is like the general talents who are able to communicate in two languages - the more, the better. Like songs that can influence one's thoughts, the changes in the learning of language can impact on our cultural development. Therefore, it is essential to seize this opportunity to enrich our bilingual-cultural soil, so as to nurture our younger generation into a strong and healthy lot that bears fruits for our nation.

 

     Secondly, I would suggest that we instill more mother tongue culture in the teaching materials. The famous passage entitled, "Bei Ying" (literally translated as 'rear or back view') by Zhu Ziqing, is a very good example. While showcasing the works of Zhu Ziqing, it brings out the theme of "eternal love" in the 5,000 years of civilisation of China through "viewing father from his behind". From Zhu's unadorned language used in the text, students can learn to appreciate family values like "blood is thicker than water" and "implicit love" between the father and the son. The story suggests that when one meets with challenges, the fatherly love can support and give one the strength to surmount all the difficulties. Students may learn about parental love for them and at the same time, when extrapolated to a macro level, it can also symbolise the love between a citizen and his/her nation, and can encourage patriotism.

     Thirdly, bilingual-bicultural teaching can positively influence the value system of our youths. Recently, I have been involved in some youth development plans. I noticed that some young people seem to lack passion for society and a sense of belonging.  In fact, juvenile delinquency appears to be on the rise and youths' value system appears challenged.  Why is it so?  Is this a result of rapid changes to social institutions, like the woes of double income family leading to latchkey kids losing a sense of aspiration and belonging? And some are just floating aimlessly with the time?  I hope that the proposed reform can seize the opportunity to include materials to inculcate our culture, value system and national identity in our youths.  A friend in China told me that their children started learning this poem "Shaoxiao li jia, lao da huan;  xianying wu gai bin mao shuai"  from an early age. It describes a person who was away from his homeland for many years, returning to his beloved hometown in his old age. Obviously much has changed and even though the village children did not know him, they could recognise him as a returner, as they recognise his local accent which remained unchanged. Similarly in Singapore, we have successful talents  studying or working overseas. Some may eventually elect to come home to Singapore to contribute to the development of our country. I think we should inculcate in our youths a sense of belonging and patriotism from young, beyond words but cultivate it in a person's paradigm and world view, so that as more goes overseas, more will return home to contribute to our nation.  There are many such values and classic stories within our Chinese, Malay and Indian society, which could be used to enhance this sense of patriotism and rootedness in one's country. We should not forget this point in our curriculum and pedagogy reform.


     Last but not the least; change comes at a price. The proposed change is an ongoing effort which will inevitably meet with challenges and pain in the process. This is particularly so in the interim periods. We will need to surmount the obstacles as we progress. Meanwhile, I hope that the Ministry of Education will pay special attention and help to the following groups of people who may be adversely affected by the proposed changes:
    

     (1)  the less well endowed who lack resources and may not have computers at home;

     (2)  those who have a keen interest in learning higher Chinese, and those who have just left the schools and polytechnics and thereby lost the chance to further their language passion; and 

     (3)  those who are caught in transition from the old to the new education systems. 

 

     Special help should be rendered, providing them with the opportunity, so that they will not be left behind and become the victims of this curriculum and pedagogy reform.
 
     Finally, let us call on all our stakeholders - students, parents, educators, community, Government and the Singapore society at large to join hands in a united effort to work towards a successful reform in the teaching of Chinese Language.

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion.

     A mother mouse brought her children out to look for food one day and they met a cat.  They were cornered by the cat and had no means to escape. At that critical moment when the cat was about to catch hold of the baby mice and eat them up, the mother mouse suddenly imitated the barking of the dog. When the cat heard the barking, it became frightened and ran away.  So the mother mouse told her children, "All these years, I have been encouraging you to be bilingual.  Now, you should know how important and useful  to be bilingual."

    

     I think the same applies to us.  In this global economy of today, Chinese is used in China and English is used in the United States. If we are monolingual, we will be handicapped.  When I was in Shanghai, I met a Singaporean.  I asked him, "How is it here?"  He said, "It is very good."  I asked him, "Why?"  He said, "I built up a strong foundation in my Chinese language when I was in primary and secondary school. When I came to China, I was like a fish in the water as I had no difficulty speaking Mandarin. I got along very well with the people here, and my business is very good."  So I asked him, "Since you are communicating with the Chinese in Mandarin, which they all know, why are these people attracted to work with you and deal with you?  What is so special about you?"  He said, "Oh, although I communicated with them in Mandarin, they know that I could also speak and understand English!  Because I know English, I would be able to have very direct contacts with the outside world."  In other words, we have different strengths from theirs.  We complement each other, and it benefits both sides.  He is a Singapore fish, but he swims very well in this very great pond in China.  He said, "I am a Singapore fish. But I am different from the Chinese fish.  That is why the Chinese people find me attractive."  So I said, "You are not only a Singapore fish.  You are a Singapore frog.   You can jump on the land and you can swim in the water.  That is why you are doing so well."   I think being bilingual is very useful.  This is our strong point and this is something we should not easily give up.  My second point is therefore this: in a world of change, this is something that should remain unchanged.  No matter how we reform our education system, we must maintain our bilingual feature so that as many Singaporeans as possible could still be effectively bilingual, though to varying degrees.

   

     My third point is: having accepted that it is not easy to be bilingual and being monolingual is no good, how should we change our method of learning and teaching? The Member for Potong Pasir said that the recommendation of this White Paper will lead to further decline in the standard of Chinese in Singapore. I do not agree.  When my children were young, I wanted them to have a healthy body, and I sent them to a swimming school to learn swimming.  Every day, they will go to the swimming pool, change into their swimming costume, do some warming up and then they plunge into the water and swim 20 or 30 laps.  It was very boring, and after some time, my children said, "This is very boring.  Can we stop the swimming lessons?"  I spoke to the coach.  I said, "They have learned how to swim. They are very healthy now.  But then, they feel that your training method is quite boring."  The coach said, "No problem."  So the next morning, half way through their swimming, the coach blew the whistle and said, "Let's go to the smaller pool.  Let's play water polo there."  Since the children found the lap-swimming very boring, he decided to add in water polo, and with water polo, the children became interested.  To play water polo well, you need to be able to swim fast.  The children now have the incentive to train harder in swimming.  By using this water polo method, he managed to enhance the interest of the children in learning swimming.  Likewise, if we keep using a boring method to teach our children, sooner or later they will find it boring and lose interest in learning.  We have to be innovative so that we can enhance their interest in the learning of the Chinese Language.

    

     Recently, I sought the views of the Chinese teachers' community. I asked them what are the things that they are most concerned with in the teaching of Chinese Language.  They told me that they are most concerned that our Singapore students are learning Chinese just for the sake of examination, and the teachers are teaching Chinese because of the school ranking.  Because of that, the interest level is getting lower and lower, the effectiveness of learning is getting poorer and poorer, and more students have lost their confidence in the learning of the language.  So we must change all these.  How do we cultivate their interest, improve the effectiveness and enhance their confidence?  I think the recommendations in this White Paper are correct.  We have to have more innovative and more flexible use of teaching methods, teaching materials and technology so that our students will have a greater interest in the learning of Chinese.  I think this is something that we have to change.


       Under the present circumstances of not being easy to practise bilingualism on the one hand, and not being practical to be monolingual on the other hand, we have to make changes to make sure that all the students would sustain the interest to learn. All teachers, parents and students will have to work together to make the teaching and learning of Chinese more interesting and more effective.  In Singapore, the overall environment is such that we are using English as our working language. With the rise of China, the opportunity of using Chinese is getting greater and greater in the larger environment of Asia.  This means speaking more English in our international dealings, and more Chinese when engaging China.  I think the present situation is actually very beneficial to Singapore because Singaporeans can make full use of our English-speaking environment to acquire a good standing in our exchanges with the western world.  At the same time, with more opportunities to learn and speak Mandarin in Asia, we will be able to enhance our standards in Mandarin so that we would play a useful role in our engagement with China.

 

     In this respect, I am hopeful that we would be able to strengthen the Chinese Language foundation of our younger generation of Singaporeans, and to make sure that they are better prepared and equipped for the future.

 

 

 

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the changes proposed by the Review Committee come at a time when the whole education edifice is being reconstructed.  Many parents, pupils, principals, administrators and teachers are reeling from the stream of changes the system has undergone over the past 12-18 months, such as through-train, new forms of school ranking, Sports School, Arts School, changes in pedagogical emphasis to continuous and project assessments, and so on and so forth. 

 

     This evening, we are here to debate yet more changes.  But fundamental issues are at work here, and however unsettling these changes might be, I believe they are vital if we are to survive as a nation.  For embedded in our mother tongues are the rich cultural heritage of the vast and ancient civilisations from which our ancestors derived and which anchors us to our Asian identity.  If we deny our roots and allow westernisation to totally engulf us, our society would be greatly impoverished.

 

     I, therefore, applaud the spirit of the Committee's recommendations and am in general agreement with the main thrusts to deal with the structural problems hindering Chinese Language learning, especially those from mainly English-speaking homes and, in extreme cases, driving some Singaporeans to migrate. 

 

     But I have four concerns which I would like to highlight using the P mnemonic and they are, firstly, pedagogical principles and approaches; secondly, prepping the next generation; thirdly, provision of adequate and appropriate teaching resources and, finally, promoting CL in the wider community.

 

Pedagogical principles and approaches

 

     The most fundamental change proposed in the current White Paper, in my opinion, is the pedagogical approach to the teaching of Chinese Language.  The Report notes that it is important to develop students' reading ability early in order to create and sustain their interest in the language.

 

     The survey conducted by the Committee confirms that an inordinate amount of time is spent on script writing and character stroke memorisation.  The Committee recommends that, across all levels, the current emphasis on writing and, in particular, character stroke memorisation for examinations - the cause of much aversion to Chinese Language learning for many children - needs to be changed.  The MOE has accepted the Committee's recommendation to shift its teaching approach to "Recognise first, Write later". 

 

      These changes in pedagogical approach are welcome as the way Chinese is taught from the time I studied the subject in the 1960s to 1970s and now appears to have remained largely unchanged, except for the introduction of hanyu pinyin and the simplified Chinese characters.  All these years, the emphasis remains on spelling, dictation and writing passages from memory even in the lower primary.

 

     I remember my son, when he was in Primary 3 some five years ago, suddenly crying out at 10 pm in the night, as he was still struggling to finish his Chinese writing homework, which can sometimes amount to about 10 pages.  He asked me, "Mom, why do I need to do so much writing in Chinese?"  A year earlier, my eldest daughter had chicken pox then and could not attend school for two weeks. I had to bring her homework back for her, one of which was Chinese writing.  And there were many pages of Chinese writing homework.  Taking pity on her as she was still rather sick, I decided to help her write some of the Chinese words.  I thought she would write some of the words on each page and I would complete the rest.  This way, she would still have an opportunity to learn the words.  When I went to school the next time to pick up another set of homework, after having handed in the earlier set, the Chinese teacher made this remark to me in Chinese:  "Zhe ge zhen de shi fei chang ji kuai. Wei shen mo zhe ge xie zi, shang ban pian tong tong shi tui de, bu guo xia ban pian tong tong shi cuo de?"  She said that it was very funny but you know for this set of homework because my daughter got the strokes right initially, but somehow got them all wrong at the back.  That was because mummy wrote it.

 

     I must say that both my older children are not averse to learning Chinese, and they got through the PSLE Chinese examinations reasonably well.  In fact, I must confess that they help me now with my Chinese speeches as their command of the language is definitely much better than mine.   However, admittedly, they had to spend a disproportionate amount of time learning Chinese Language in order to do well in the examinations.  And I believe this story finds echoes in many, many families in Singapore.

 

     Making learning Chinese more interesting through the use of more songs, verses, reading, recitation and other activities with less emphasis on character memorisation for the younger children would help avoid killing the interest in and a joy of learning Chinese for these children.  Hopefully, this new approach would, as the Committee envisages in the Report, allow the students to recognise enough characters to read age-appropriate children's literature and thus enthuse them to read at a younger age. 

 

     Yet, the Report also seems to imply that the pedadogical approach of "Recognise first, Write later" is not yet conventional wisdom in language learning, even in CL-speaking countries.  I wonder if it is then wise to base such a fundamental shift in teaching approach on what seems to be something experimental at this stage.  Also, as a substantial number of CL educators will tell us that writing and reading are mutually reinforcing and one should not be emphasised at the expense of the other.  How then can we ensure that we will not be dumbing down overall standards, while taking cognisance of the genuine difficulties some pupils face in CL learning?  This, in fact, is the de facto primary concern of the Chinese intelligentsia which has led to much public debate and misgivings over the changes made to CL learning through the years. 

 

     Each successive change to Chinese Language learning has been largely seen by the Chinese intelligentsia as yielding to populist pressures which will result in lower standards of language learning and, ultimately, a culturally stunted generation of younger people.  Even the new pedagogical approach is seen by some as a form of concession to pupils with weaker language aptitude.

 

     Additionally, the CL learning seems to be converging with the learning of the other subjects as schools move towards a more continuous school-based assessment regime.  This could well create more stress for pupils who have been drilled by years of emphasis on what the Report calls "high stakes national examinations".  I urge the Ministry to promote group-based assignments that can allow mingling of pupils of varying abilities and their project work.  Exposure in this way could help the weaker pupils.  The stronger ones will still be able to shine in their individual assessments.  I also urge that such project work for CL learning be done in classrooms as much as possible to avoid parental assistance, although speaking from personal experience, this is unlikely to be forthcoming even from the English-speaking homes. 

 

 

     I further urge the MOE to monitor the effects that such project-based work have on pupils' stress levels and learning outcomes.  The Report also talks about resting of a wider range of skills instead of what is essentially memorisation of Chinese characters.  Again, this follows the direction the teaching of non-language subjects are taking.  But perhaps we should have graded levels of difficulty and confine such testing of high-order skills to CL and HCL, and not the Bridging or Reinforcement modules, which are essentially coaching classes. 

 

Prepping the next generation

 

     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as part of my personal preparation for this debate, I looked up the Ministerial Statement by then-DPM Lee on the last CL review in 1999.  I am struck by the fact that there is an uncanny similarity between the review at that time and what we are now debating.  The problems that led to this present review were already highlighted some five years ago, eg, rising percentages of EL-speaking homes, growing economic and political importance of China, and the need for a Chinese elite.  The objective of wanting every Singaporean to study his mother tongue for as long as possible and to as high a level as he is capable of was also similar.  In fact, the same company, Forbes Research, was also commissioned to do a survey for that review.  However, most of the recommendations were then targeted at secondary schools.  This present review is now moving the changes upstream, to the primary school levels, in due recognition that it is better to start early and to have a more differentiated and customised approach to allow students to learn as far as their abilities allow.

 

     Sir, should we then not consider shifting these changes even further up the education chain to the pre-primary levels?  While I recognise that pre-primary education is not part of the national education system but very much left to the private sector and social sector initiatives, there is implicit recognition that basics count in CL learning, and the earlier we start exposure of the language to our pupils, the better.  Given that English-speaking homes are still on the rise, the pre-primary learning environment becomes a crucial bridge for pupils to acquire foundational CL skills.  Perhaps the Bridging modules the review spoke of should be developed with a pre-primary orientation in view.  I certainly hope that we will not have to debate another review committee's report on CL in pre-primary schools five years from now.

 

Providing adequate and appropriate resources

 

     I find it quite perplexing and rather ironic but at the same time amusing that, besides the students, many teachers are now also saying that the textbooks and teaching materials are uninteresting and turn off students from wanting to read them.  Textbook writers, we are now told, were hitherto constrained in their ability to produce more interesting materials, as they are to stick to five stipulated moral themes and also characters from a prescribed word list.  Teachers also blame the current examination format for limiting what they can do to make Chinese lessons lively and interesting.  To meet the demands of the curriculum, they say that they have to resort to tried and tested repetitive drilling of students.  Yet, I distinctly remember that some three years ago at a dialogue session, I had made the remark that perhaps we can review the teaching method for CL as the emphasis on rote learning on spelling, dictation, etc, does not seem to have changed over the years and this is off-putting to students.  Back came the almost immediate retort from a teacher that this is the way Chinese Language ought to be taught, there is no short cut.  I was taken aback, but shrugged it off since I am clearly no authority on the language. 

 

     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I trust there will not be serious resistance to these changes from CL teachers who are themselves the implementors of this new approach to CL learning.  Perhaps the sentiment is not shared by all Chinese Language teachers.  But I believe that there are Chinese Language teachers who do not necessarily subscribe to the newly advocated approach to teaching and learning CL.  Also, if the issues and problems that have been highlighted were known all along by the teachers, why was nothing done about it till now?  In fact, it was reported in the press that, when interviewed, a teacher had said that she had heard about the methods emphasising character recognition for a long time now and was eager to try out this new approach.  Were there no avenues of feedback to MOE for the teachers?  Or, if such feedback were given, why were they not acted upon?  What then would trigger follow-up action on feedback received from teachers and principals who are at the ground and have first-hand knowledge of the relevance and effectiveness of MOE's prescribed policies?

 

     Just as the pedagogical approach to teaching CL is the most fundamental change in the current review, the key responsibility of implementing the changes appears to fall on the teachers.  Among others, the Report calls for teachers to be trained such that they can identify students who could benefit from the Bridging or Reinforcement modules and advise parents accordingly early on in the school year.  Teachers are also called upon to use creative and innovative tools and techniques, including IT project work, etc, to enthuse and sustain children's interest in the learning of CL.  Has the Ministry already formulated ideas as to how teachers can be trained adequately to enable them to assess the student's learning abilities and, ultimately, the modules he should take?  What diagnostic tools would MOE make available to help the teacher in this task, which may be challenged by the parents? 

 

     Clearly, to ensure that the recommended approaches to teaching and learning CL, including the new mantra of "Recognise first, Write later", more innovative teaching methods, etc, yield positive results, existing and new CL teachers must be adequately and appropriately trained and equipped.  There is no short cut to this process, and it will take time.  Teachers' workload must also be recalibrated so that they will not only have sufficient time to be trained or retrained, but also have time to prepare more creative and interactive lesson projects and tests.  Furthermore, even as the slew of sweeping changes are being phased in, and the jury is still out on the success of these changes, the MOE must have built-in mechanisms to monitor and review these changes and gather feedback from the teachers who are implementing the changes, and not hesitate to initiate further changes, if required.  Learning from the experiences of the previous review, the MOE clearly does not have a monopoly on wisdom.  Therefore, it should develop a dynamic and flexible feedback mechanism to enable it to make timely revisions and refinements to the ambitious changes it is implementing and, hence, ensure its success.  This is because we really cannot afford to fail this time, with such fundamental changes and after so many attempts trying to reverse the tide.  Otherwise, there are implications on the success of our bilingual policy, with mother tongue learning having seen the most number of changes in the education system to-date. 

 

Promoting the language in the wider community

 

     Sir, the broader problem we face is one of language competition.  The rising use of English in homes, and probably the death of Chinese-medium schools close to 20 years ago, stems from its universal acceptance as a global language of commerce and our Singaporean families' well-known pragmatism.  If we cast our eyes 20 to 30 years hence, the yuan may become a world currency on par with the US dollar, the Euro and the yen.  Chinese may then, likewise, be on par with English or, arguably, even overtake it.  There will always be a tension between older Chinese Singaporeans and possibly the Chinese elite and intellectuals on one hand, and the English-speaking folks on the other hand.  Some schools are often typecast as "ang mo pai" - English tag, versus "tng nan pai" - Chinese tag, to reflect their pupils' standard of CL ability.  This is unfortunate, but perhaps quite unavoidable.  I think parents also have their roles to play in this whole equation.  They need to make a conscious effort to provide as conducive an environment for their children's CL learning.  Of course, that presumes that the parents themselves must attain a certain proficiency in the language and be able to communicate in Chinese to their children in a real-life everyday setting and in a natural way.  Perhaps this is the reason why Malays have done better in their mother tongue, as more Malay families speak mother tongue at home. 

 

     To assist families, perhaps, our television stations, as my other parliamentary colleagues have alluded to, should re-allocate more prime-time slots to Chinese educational programmes that families can enjoy watching together.  We cannot underestimate the power of television and its influence in language acquisition, especially for young minds.  My friend's four-year-old daughter thinks that Olinda is better than Sylvester and Taufik any time.  Also, the Chinese programming should be less sublimal in content, as some of our Chinese serials are currently perceived as Government propaganda.  This can be quite off-putting.  Instead, they should be more fun and educational. 

 

     In some countries, the learning of second languages is a politically-charged issue, dividing communities and creating much social friction.  While we place considerable emphasis on CL learning for reasons of economic survival and national preservation, we must never let our Malay and Indian fellow countrymen feel that their own MTLs are less worthy of such a comprehensive review to strengthen their own ethnic community's social and historical roots.  Sir, I am pleased the Ministry will be addressing this issue soon. 

 

     With this, Sir, I support the Report's recommendations.

     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for allowing me to join in this debate on the White Paper.

 

     Firstly, I must congratulate the Ministry on this initiative to form the Committee to review the Chinese Language curriculum.  The recommendations to have a differentiated approach to the learning of the Chinese Language is most welcomed, on the premise that children can now progress in the language at their own ability level and at their own pace, to the best capabilities that the system can allow.  Students who develop a love for the language can also opt for the enrichment modules.  This is a sound approach, and reading the White Paper also sets one wondering if we could have looked into such changes much earlier. 

 

     Nevertheless, what is fulfilling is the Minister's assertion earlier that these changes mean greater flexibility and enjoyment.  The word "enjoyment" is precious, because it is great to bring joy as we learn a language.  The word "enjoyment" is seldom associated with the acquisition of a second language.  So it is my hope that we will not stray from the concept of enjoying the learning of a second language.  Speakers before me have already outlined many ways of bringing joy into language learning.  All that I will say at this point is that one sure way of taking the fun out is to introduce at too early a stage the rigours of memorising grammar rules and characters, and identifying sentence structures and word type.  Children can recoil from the language learning but stay with it out of an obligation to the system an understanding of why it is important to go to school, love for their parents, teachers and tuition teachers.  And they have not had fun through a demanding curriculum and workload or perhaps weak teaching techniques.  So, enjoyment is very crucial to the learning of a language. 

 

     Next, to some concerns that I have.  The current bilingual policy is one that limits choice of language by ethnic group.  I am asking if we can make it easier for perhaps the Malay and Indian communities to also study Chinese as a second language.  Currently, prior approval is needed from the Ministry.  While English is our administrative language, Chinese is fast becoming a language of social discourse and for business.  In fact, in certain service-oriented industries, being Chinese-speaking has become a pre-requisite for the job. 

 

     Let me cite an example of how this phenomenon takes place on the ground.  I met an Indian lady from the Women's Executive Committee of a CC at a function, and was intrigued when she told me that their meetings are conducted in Mandarin and she depends on translations from her volunteer colleagues to know what to do as a volunteer.  She is not unduly upset.  Nevertheless, she is frustrated.  If this is the kind of scenario that we have, then as our society is moving, this phenomenon needs both careful moderation and monitoring for social cohesion reasons, as well as we also need to really consider whether we can open up the learning of Mandarin to other ethnic groups and help them along.

 

     I would also like to cite an example of how this can be done.  At Alexandra Hospital where I work, up to recently, the President of the Mandarin Toastmasters' Club was our Chief Pharmacist, Ms Fatimah Mohidin Kutty, who is an Indian Muslim and a Malayalee.  Tamil is not her mother tongue, but she did Mandarin in school without tuition.  She only had tuition for her "O" and "A" levels.  Her two sons today, however, do Tamil.  Both

parents are not Tamil-speaking. She opted for Tamil because she heard that the Mandarin syllabus has gotten much tougher.  Of course now, she does wonder if it was a good choice under this differentiated approach.   The point here is that there are parents from other communities who would like to have this option of letting their children study Mandarin.  

 

      The other concern that I have is over Tamil as a second language.  I was very happy to hear earlier that the Minister has said that there would be a taskforce that would also be set up to look into the issues of what can be done where Tamil is concerned.  From what I have gathered, the Tamil standards are considered by some quarters to be too high.  There is also a concern about how other Indian languages are being offered, monitored and how the examination processes take place.  Perhaps, these could be terms of reference.

 

     Lastly, Singapore's bilingual policy is one step in getting us closer to our cultural roots while we use English for administrative purposes.  But with globalisation and markets that can open up in the Arab world, India and South America, we need to be more nimble as we acquire languages.  Even as we focus on English and mother tongue, we need to include, in my opinion, a component in the curriculum that deals with multi-culturalism and diversity.  Even as we sink roots deeper into our individual cultures, a comprehensive approach to multi-culturalism will make the Singaporean an individual who is ever-ready to appreciate other cultures, who will go into the world, wherever he or she is needed to go, without a trace of cultural imperialism, as Singaporeans whom we can be proud of.
